lines.text: Enter a Messenger

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: What, ho! my lord!

lines.speaker: hastings
lines.text: [Within]  Who knocks at the door?

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: A messenger from the Lord Stanley.
Enter HASTINGS

lines.speaker: hastings
lines.text: What is't o'clock?

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: Upon the stroke of four.

lines.speaker: hastings
lines.text: Cannot thy master sleep these tedious nights?

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: So it should seem by that I have to say. First, he commends him to your noble lordship.

lines.speaker: hastings
lines.text: And then?

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: And then he sends you word He dreamt to-night the boar had razed his helm: Besides, he says there are two councils held; And that may be determined at the one which may make you and him to rue at the other. Therefore he sends to know your lordship's pleasure, If presently you will take horse with him, And with all speed post with him toward the north, To shun the danger that his soul divines.

lines.speaker: hastings
lines.text: Go, fellow, go, return unto thy lord; Bid him not fear the separated councils His honour and myself are at the one, And at the other is my servant Catesby Where nothing can proceed that toucheth us Whereof I shall not have intelligence. Tell him his fears are shallow, wanting instance: And for his dreams, I wonder he is so fond To trust the mockery of unquiet slumbers To fly the boar before the boar pursues, Were to incense the boar to follow us And make pursuit where he did mean no chase. Go, bid thy master rise and come to me And we will both together to the Tower, Where, he shall see, the boar will use us kindly.

lines.speaker: messenger
lines.text: My gracious lord, I'll tell him what you say.
Exit
Enter CATESBY

lines.speaker: catesby
lines.text: Many good morrows to my noble lord!

lines.speaker: hastings
lines.text: Good morrow, Catesby; you are early stirring What news, what news, in this our tottering state?

lines.speaker: catesby
lines.text: It is a reeling world, indeed, my lord; And I believe twill never stand upright Tim Richard wear the garland of the realm.

lines.speaker: hastings
lines.text: How! wear the garland! dost thou mean the crown?

lines.speaker: catesby
lines.text: Ay, my good lord.

lines.speaker: hastings
lines.text: I'll have this crown of mine cut from my shoulders Ere I will see the crown so foul misplaced. But canst thou guess that he doth aim at it?

lines.speaker: catesby
lines.text: Ay, on my life; and hopes to find forward Upon his party for the gain thereof: And thereupon he sends you this good news, That this same very day your enemies, The kindred of the queen, must die at Pomfret.

lines.speaker: hastings
lines.text: Indeed, I am no mourner for that news, Because they have been still mine enemies: But, that I'll give my voice on Richard's side, To bar my master's heirs in true descent, God knows I will not do it, to the death.

lines.speaker: catesby
lines.text: God keep your lordship in that gracious mind!

lines.speaker: hastings
lines.text: But I shall laugh at this a twelve-month hence, That they who brought me in my master's hate I live to look upon their tragedy. I tell thee, Catesby--

lines.speaker: catesby
lines.text: What, my lord?

lines.speaker: hastings
lines.text: Ere a fortnight make me elder, I'll send some packing that yet think not on it.

lines.speaker: catesby
lines.text: 'Tis a vile thing to die, my gracious lord, When men are unprepared and look not for it.

lines.speaker: hastings
lines.text: O monstrous, monstrous! and so falls it out With Rivers, Vaughan, Grey: and so 'twill do With some men else, who think themselves as safe As thou and I; who, as thou know'st, are dear To princely Richard and to Buckingham.

lines.speaker: catesby
lines.text: The princes both make high account of you; For they account his head upon the bridge.
Aside

lines.speaker: hastings
lines.text: I know they do; and I have well deserved it. Come on, come on; where is your boar-spear, man? Fear you the boar, and go so unprovided?
Enter STANLEY

lines.speaker: stanley
lines.text: My lord, good morrow; good morrow, Catesby: You may jest on, but, by the holy rood, I do not like these several councils, I.

lines.speaker: hastings
lines.text: My lord, I hold my life as dear as you do yours; And never in my life, I do protest, Was it more precious to me than 'tis now: Think you, but that I know our state secure, I would be so triumphant as I am?

lines.speaker: stanley
lines.text: The lords at Pomfret, when they rode from London, Were jocund, and supposed their state was sure, And they indeed had no cause to mistrust; But yet, you see how soon the day o'ercast. This sudden stag of rancour I misdoubt: Pray God, I say, I prove a needless coward! What, shall we toward the Tower? the day is spent.

lines.speaker: hastings
lines.text: Come, come, have with you. Wot you what, my lord? To-day the lords you talk of are beheaded.

lines.speaker: lord stanley
lines.text: They, for their truth, might better wear their heads Than some that have accused them wear their hats. But come, my lord, let us away.
Enter a Pursuivant

lines.speaker: hastings
lines.text: Go on before; I'll talk with this good fellow. How now, sirrah! how goes the world with thee?
Exeunt STANLEY and CATESBY

lines.speaker: pursuivant
lines.text: The better that your lordship please to ask.

lines.speaker: hastings
lines.text: I tell thee, man, 'tis better with me now Than when I met thee last where now we meet: Then was I going prisoner to the Tower, By the suggestion of the queen's allies; But now, I tell thee--keep it to thyself-- This day those enemies are put to death, And I in better state than e'er I was.

lines.speaker: pursuivant
lines.text: God hold it, to your honour's good content!

lines.speaker: hastings
lines.text: Gramercy, fellow: there, drink that for me.
Throws him his purse

lines.speaker: pursuivant
lines.text: God save your lordship!
Exit
Enter a Priest

lines.speaker: priest
lines.text: Well met, my lord; I am glad to see your honour.

lines.speaker: hastings
lines.text: I thank thee, good Sir John, with all my heart. I am in your debt for your last exercise; Come the next Sabbath, and I will content you.
He whispers in his ear
Enter BUCKINGHAM

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: What, talking with a priest, lord chamberlain? Your friends at Pomfret, they do need the priest; Your honour hath no shriving work in hand.

lines.speaker: hastings
lines.text: Good faith, and when I met this holy man, Those men you talk of came into my mind. What, go you toward the Tower?

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: I do, my lord; but long I shall not stay I shall return before your lordship thence.

lines.speaker: hastings
lines.text: 'Tis like enough, for I stay dinner there.

lines.speaker: buckingham
lines.text: [Aside]  And supper too, although thou know'st it not. Come, will you go?

lines.speaker: hastings
lines.text: I'll wait upon your lordship.
Exeunt
